name: Writing Simple Expressions: One Step (Expression to Words)

skills.name: Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention

explanations.A: Not quite. Although this is a fraction, can you think about it in terms of a calculation ?
explanations.B: You're close! Be careful with the order. Remember it matters the order that we divide in.
explanations.C: Not quite. It doesn't mean multiply. What operation is it when it's written like a fraction? Think of the calculation...
explanations.D: Written in a fraction with x in the numerator and 7 as the denominator means the quotient of x and 7.

explanations.A: You're close! Be careful with the order. Remember it matters the order that we divide in.
explanations.B: Not quite. It doesn't mean multiply. What operation is it when it's written like a fraction? Think of the calculation...
explanations.C: Written in a fraction with t in the numerator and 4 as the denominator means the quotient of t and 4.
explanations.D: Not quite. Although this is a fraction, can you think about it in terms of a calculation ?

explanations.A: Not quite. You have stated what terms are there, but which mathematical operation is happening?
explanations.B: Not quite! Look carefully. Which mathematical operation is happening between the 9 and the h?
explanations.C: h more than 9 is the same as adding h onto 9.
explanations.D: Close! Although it does mean 9 plus h, have a look at the answer you have chosen - does it fit the expression?

explanations.A: Look carefully at the expression. Which mathematical operation is happening?
explanations.B: Addition is commutative so we can add in any order. That means 6+p is the same as 6 more than p or p more than 6.
explanations.C: Not quite. You have stated the terms that are there, but which mathematical operation is happening?
explanations.D: Not quite! Look carefully. Which mathematical operation is happening between the 9 and the h?

explanations.A: It matters the order we subtract in. We are starting with d and subtracting 12 from that, so d - 12 means d minus 12.
explanations.B: Close! You have the correct operation, but remember it matters what order we subtract in. What are you starting with and what are you taking from that?
explanations.C: Not quite! Although when we're finding a difference we do subtract, the order always matters. Think carefully about what this expression is saying...
explanations.D: Almost! Read out the answer you have chosen, does it match the expression exactly?

explanations.A: Close! You have the correct operation, but remember it matters what order we subtract in. What are you starting with and what are you taking from that?
explanations.B: Not quite! Although when we're finding a difference we do subtract, the order always matters. Think carefully about what this expression is saying...
explanations.C: Almost! Read out the answer you have chosen, does it match the expression exactly?
explanations.D: It matters the order we subtract in. We are starting with f and subtracting 9 from that so f - 9 means f minus 9.

explanations.A: Not quite! Think carefully about what the dot represents between the number and the letter. What mathematical operation is it?
explanations.B: The dot is used to represent multiplication. Multiplying by 3 is the same as tripling.
explanations.C: Not quite! Think carefully about what the dot represents between the number and the letter. What mathematical operation is it?
explanations.D: Not quite! Think carefully about what the dot represents between the number and the letter. What mathematical operation is it?

explanations.A: The dot is used to represent multiplication. Multiplying by 2 is the same as doubling.
explanations.B: Not quite! Think carefully about what the dot represents between the number and the letter. What mathematical operation is it?
explanations.C: Not quite! Think carefully about what the dot represents between the number and the letter. What mathematical operation is it?
explanations.D: Not quite! Think carefully about what the dot represents between the number and the letter. What mathematical operation is it?

explanations.A: Addition is commutative so it can be done in any order. If you wanted 2 more than g, what mathematical operation would you do?
explanations.B: If you wanted the sum of g and 2, what mathematical operation would you do? Think about what the word 'sum' means.
explanations.C: Remember addition is commutative so it can be done in any order.
explanations.D: Adding 2 to something and multiplying by 2 (or doubling) are not the same thing. So 2 + g does not mean doubling the value of g.

explanations.A: Remember addition is commutative so can be done in any order.
explanations.B: Adding 7 to something and multiplying by 7 are not the same thing. So 7 + k does not mean 7 times the value of k.
explanations.C: If you wanted k more than 7, what mathematical operation would you do? What does more than mean?
explanations.D: If you wanted the sum of 7 and k, what mathematical operation would you do? Think about what the word 'sum' means.
